The Star Trek transporter breaks matter down to energy (or chunks the size of the Planck constant), transmit these chunks to the other transporter and reassembles them in the original order.

The original and the reassembled version are made of exactly the same energy (and particles and molecules) and have the same quantum state.

The transporter cannot be used to make perfect copies because quantum state cannot be copied (no cloning theorem). Even if you made copies, there would always be one original.

The "transporter buffer" kind of works against your point.  Transporters basically wait for confirmation from the target zone that the transport succeeded.  When a transport fails, the information is taken from the buffer, and the subject is rebuilt at the home location.  This is how Riker was duplicated.  A simple network error.  The home location didn't receive acknowledgement from the target that the transport succeeded, even though it did, so it rebuilt the "original" at the home location, while the target location got a Riker and went on their way.

here's my thoughts about this:
1st we have to have a clear definition of what "you" means and therefore what "you" are. I don't know if the quantum properties are enough to preserve things like personality and memories so for the sake of the argument I'll assume they are. In this way I see quantum teleportation as being analogous to when the cut & paste say a sound file. What you're deleting, remembering and rebuilding in another place are the bits (for non computer nerds "bits" are the smallest units of data that computers understand) of which they're made. You could define that particular file as being the physical location on the hard disk on which the bits are stored and therefore the copy would simply be a cloned file i.e. not the original. I believe that most people (even if they don't, I still do) would say this isn't true because both the clone and the cloned are made up of the same bits, they sound the same etc so why should they be distinct from one another (i'd be interested if anyone could give me a good reason why they should be, both when talking about sound files and about people). Therefore, if the quantum information is what's being copied and imprinted onto some new matter then why should the clone be distinct from the cloned?
Anyway, just some food for thought...

Regardless of how the teleportation actually works, the philosophical questions of individuality are predicated on the illusion of atomic identity. I am not "me" because of a particular arrangement of quantum states in my brain, I am "me" because the various parts of my brain work together in such a way that I perceive myself as an individual with a single identity, a set of more-or-less stable qualities, and a sense of moral entitlement (I have certain rights, privileges, and responsibilities). If I have to consider whether or not future-teleported-me is still "me", I also have to wonder if anything else that could possibly change the quantum state of my brain changes who I am on some fundamental level. What happens to me if I walk through a strong magnetic field? What if I alter the chemical composition of my body, or something I ingest biases my meat-computer towards one behavior or another? As far as how we view ourselves, the fact that we even have to wonder whether this matters means that it doesn't matter - as long as the illusion of self-hood holds, I am myself. The real problems here are legal and social. If there's two of me, who's dating my girlfriend? Who owns my car? Who has my social security number?

The domain of the problem isn't restricted to teleportation or physical copying. As we get closer to digitizing consciousness, society is going to have to suss out these details, and we may even have to completely abandon our traditional sense of self entirely. The alternative is nothing short of chaos.

Every day you wake up, you are not really you.

Your body loses millions of cells every minute, and replaces those cells with new ones, so that after every 7 years, not a single cell remains the same.

Consciousness works the same way. Electrons fire in your brain to form synapses, and then new electrons fire to create more synapses... Those synapses are similar, but not exactly the same as previous synapses, which is why over time, you as a person feel and act differently than many years ago... Even if ever so slightly.

Consciousness is therefore nothing but an illusion at any given moment in time (which itself is also just an illusion ;) )

there is a quantum mechanical interpretation called orchestrated objective reduction which proposes that once a superposition approaches a classical mechanics scale, it automatically collapses. this interpretation has been proposed by the physicist who invented it, Sir Roger Penrose, and anesthesiologist Dr Stuart Hameroff to account for the nature of consciousness as a non-deterministic quantum computational phenomenon. they propose that the tryptophan, in the tubulin proteins that make up the microtubules of the cytoskeleton  of your neurons, forms hydrophobic pockets in which the uncertainty of the position of the tryptophan sets up quantum computations along the microtubule. These quantum computations collapse when enough of them interact with each other that they approach a classical system in scale and then collapse, triggering  the final calculation to be converted to a classical signal and sent to the next neuron.  the next neuron then processes this information, incorporating it into it's own quantum calculation. this continues on down the neural pathways and results in what they call non-deterministic decision making, aka consciousness.

(1) Transporters kill you.
(2) It doesn't matter how fast/slow the transporter works or where it transports you, they still kill you.

exactly the position you were at before. Taking our assumptions into
consideration, this would kill you and leave a copy of you that thinks
it's you.

Thus you never exist for more than a moment. You live for a flock second, die, and get replaced by someone who thinks they're you.
